misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different program instead of the required grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a grade-to-letter-grade calculator using conditional ranges. This indicates a misunderstanding or misreading of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I believe the task is to read coordinates for two points and compute the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read a single numeric grade from 0 to 100, use conditional ranges (if/else-if/else) to determine whether it is an A, B, C, D, or F, and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade.
Program never uses conditionals or Boolean ranges for letter grades.
Output describes the distance between two points instead of a letter grade.
No handling of grade ranges 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, or below 60.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misinterpreted the problem statement or reused code from a different assignment about distance between two points.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and start from scratch: prompt for a single numeric grade, store it in a variable, and use an if/else-if/else chain to check the specified ranges and print the correct letter grade.
related_concepts: Designing conditionals based on numeric ranges
Basic input and output in Java
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program is dedicated to distance calculation; there is no trace of grade input, range checks, or letter grade output.

evidence.note: Reads four coordinate values instead of a single numeric grade, showing the program is not a grade calculator.

evidence.snippet:
double distanceBetweenPoints = Math.sqrt(xDifference * xDifference + yDifference * yDifference);

System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distanceBetweenPoints);
evidence.note: Computes and prints the distance between two points; there is no conditional logic or letter grade output.
